            SUPPORT, TRAINING AND EMPLOYMENT,TF031409-TUNISIA ; ALGERIA - EDUCATION

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and institutional development impacts
            substantial. Positive lessons suggest that the definition of
            realistic objectives, closely tied to the Government's
            priorities in relation to education reforms, was essential
            for the project success, and, the success of individual
            components is, by and large, due to the sustained commitment
            of the relevant government officials. Moreover, the sound
            analytical preparation, and policy consultations facilitated
            implementation, and achievement of development objectives,
            while the flexibility in the training approach enabled a
            responsive training redefinition, tailored to specific
            needs, as suggested by the successful in-service training
            for teachers, which showed positive effects on the quality
            of education. Negative lessons however, indicate that
            institutional weaknesses were apparent in the drafting of
            the education assessment system, which prevented the
            application by the Ministry of Education (MoE), to include
            this key component for quality improvement (thus postponed
            to the following operation). Furthermore, the lack of
            experience with procurement guidelines, was conducive to
            delays, and, the absence of integrated software, to
            facilitate a proactive project management prevented higher
            project ratings. Unfortunately, no provisions were made in
            project accounting practices, to quantify, and include
            in-kind contributions from MoE, as part of the total
            expenditures by the Government.
